headline: Global warming set to break key 1.5C limit for first time

annotations.paragraph: Environment correspondent
annotations.reason: This is a job title and does not contribute to the article's core story.

annotations.paragraph: Science Photo Library
annotations.reason: This is likely a credit for an image and does not contribute to the article's core story.

annotations.paragraph: Our overheating world is likely to break a key temperature limit for the first time over the next few years, scientists predict.
annotations.reason: Introduces the main premise of the article about breaking a temperature limit.

annotations.paragraph: Researchers say there's now a 66% chance we will pass the 1.5C global warming threshold between now and 2027.
annotations.reason: Provides specific data and timeline related to the main premise.

annotations.paragraph: The chances are rising due to emissions from human activities and a likely El Niño weather pattern later this year.
annotations.reason: Explains the reasons behind the increased likelihood of passing the temperature threshold.

annotations.paragraph: If the world passes the limit, scientists stress the breach, while worrying, will likely be temporary.
annotations.reason: Provides direct commentary on the potential temporary nature of breaching the 1.5C limit.

annotations.paragraph: Hitting the threshold would mean the world is 1.5C warmer than it was during the second half of the 19th Century, before fossil fuel emissions from industrialisation really began to ramp up.
annotations.reason: Offers essential context about what the 1.5C threshold represents historically.

annotations.paragraph: And breaking the limit even for just one year is a worrying sign that warming is accelerating and not slowing down.
annotations.reason: Provides direct commentary on the implications of breaching the limit.

annotations.paragraph: The 1.5C figure has become a symbol of global climate change negotiations. Countries agreed to "pursue efforts" to limit global temperature rises to 1.5C under the 2015 Paris agreement.
annotations.reason: Gives relevant context about the significance of the 1.5C figure in international agreements.

annotations.paragraph: Going over 1.5C every year for a decade or two would see far greater impacts of warming, such as longer heatwaves, more intense storms and wildfires.
annotations.reason: Discusses potential long-term impacts of consistently exceeding the 1.5C limit.

annotations.paragraph: But passing the level in one of the next few years would not mean that the Paris limit had been broken. Scientists say there is still time to restrict global warming by cutting emissions sharply.
annotations.reason: Provides essential context about the implications of passing the 1.5C level and the possibility of mitigating actions.

annotations.paragraph: Since 2020 the World Meteorological Organisation has been giving an estimate of the chances of the world breaking the 1.5C threshold in any one year.
annotations.reason: Introduces relevant background information about the monitoring of the 1.5C threshold.

annotations.paragraph: Back then they predicted there was less than a 20% chance of breaking 1.5C in the five years ahead.
annotations.reason: Provides historical context on the changing predictions regarding the 1.5C threshold.

annotations.paragraph: By last year this had increased to 50%, and now it's jumped to 66%, which the scientists say means it's "more likely than not."
annotations.reason: Updates the reader on the current likelihood of surpassing the 1.5C threshold, which is central to the article's premise.

annotations.paragraph: The figure is not a direct measure of the world's temperature but an indicator of how much or how little the Earth has warmed or cooled compared to the long term global average.
annotations.reason: Clarifies the meaning of the 1.5C figure, contributing to the reader's understanding of the topic.

annotations.paragraph: Scientists use average temperature data from the period between 1850-1900 as a measure of how hot the world was before our modern reliance on coal, oil and gas.
annotations.reason: Provides context on how pre-industrial temperatures are measured, relevant to understanding the significance of the 1.5C limit.

annotations.paragraph: For decades they believed that if the world warmed by around 2C that would be the threshold of dangerous impacts - but in 2018 they significantly revised this estimate, showing that going past 1.5C would be calamitous for the world.
annotations.reason: Explains the revised understanding of the 1.5C limit's significance, directly related to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: Over the past few decades our overheating world has nudged the mercury up so that in 2016, the warmest on record, global temperatures were 1.28C above the pre-industrial figure.
annotations.reason: Provides historical data on temperature increases, relevant to the discussion of approaching the 1.5C limit.

annotations.paragraph: And in the years between now and then they believe there's a very solid chance the 1.5C limit will be surpassed for the first time.
annotations.reason: Directly addresses the likelihood of surpassing the 1.5C limit, central to the article's premise.

annotations.paragraph: "We really are now within reach of a temporary exceedance of 1.5C for the annual mean temperature, and that's the first time in human history we've been that close," said Prof Adam Scaife, head of long range forecasts at the Met Office, who compile the data from weather and climate agencies around the world.
annotations.reason: Provides expert commentary on the proximity to exceeding the 1.5C limit, relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: "I think that's perhaps the most stark and obvious and simplest statistic that we've got in the report," he told a news conference.
annotations.reason: The quote is vague and does not provide specific information about the 1.5C limit.

annotations.paragraph: The researchers stress that temperatures would have to stay at or above 1.5C for 20 years to be able to say the Paris agreement threshold had been passed.
annotations.reason: This provides important context about the conditions needed to officially surpass the Paris agreement threshold.

annotations.paragraph: "This report does not mean that we will permanently exceed the 1.5C level specified in the Paris Agreement which refers to long-term warming over many years," said WMO Secretary-General Prof. Petteri Taalas
annotations.reason: The quote clarifies that the 1.5C level breach is not permanent, which is relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: "However, WMO is sounding the alarm that we will breach the 1.5C level on a temporary basis with increasing frequency," he said.
annotations.reason: This statement highlights the increasing frequency of temporary breaches, directly related to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: There are two key elements - the first is the continuing high levels of carbon emissions from human activities that despite a fall during the pandemic are still going up.
annotations.reason: This provides context on the causes of the temperature increase, relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: The second, critical part is the likely appearance of El Niño, a weather phenomenon with global implications.
annotations.reason: Introduces El Niño as a significant factor affecting global temperatures.

annotations.paragraph: For the last three years the world has been experiencing a La Niña event which has dampened climate warming to some extent.
annotations.reason: Provides context on recent climate conditions affecting global warming.

annotations.paragraph: But the extra heat that El Niño will bring to the surface of the Pacific will likely push the global temperature to a new high next year.
annotations.reason: Explains the expected impact of El Niño on global temperatures.

annotations.paragraph: However there is still uncertainty around the onset and scale of the event.
annotations.reason: Highlights the uncertainty surrounding the El Niño event.

annotations.paragraph: "It's worth noting that a lot of our forecasts that are being made now for the El Niño that we think is developing this winter, are showing pretty big amplitude," Prof Scaife told reporters.
annotations.reason: Provides expert commentary on the potential strength of the upcoming El Niño.

annotations.paragraph: "But to actually predict the magnitude, or a subsequent event within the five-year period, we can't give the exact dates of that beyond this one year ahead, so it could be in three or four years from now we get to two and a half degree El Niño and that might be the one that does it. "
annotations.reason: The paragraph discusses the uncertainty in predicting the exact timing of events related to global warming, which is relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: The Arctic will experience warming at a greater level than many regions, with the temperature anomaly expected to be three times as large as the global figure over the next five northern hemisphere winters.
annotations.reason: This provides specific information about the impact of global warming in the Arctic, which is relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: Northern Europe including the UK will likely experience increased rainfall for the May to September period over the next five years, the report says.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific regional impacts of global warming, which is relevant to the headline.
